topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0 Alpha: Creating a Shared L3 Management Network

body.p: After the HPE Helion OpenStack cloud is installed, in order for the management network to function across the
You must perform the following tasks using CLI commands, the HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Horizon interface, and the HPE Virtualized Services Directory Architect (VSD Architect) interface.
Note: If you are deploying the KVM deployment, you do not need to perform these tasks.
The following diagram illustrates the general workflow of the post-installation configuration.

ol.li:
Launch the VSD architect:
Using Chrome or Safari, navigate to https://<VSD_address>:8443/ and enter user name, password and organization. See the DCN documentation if you need to locate the IP address for the VSD.
User Name: Csproot Password: csproot Org: csp VSD Server : auto
Click the arrow icon to log in.
Right click Helion_Nuage_Integration to create a new organization.
Enter a name, description, and password for the organization.
Click Create.

section.title: Add VLAN to VRS-G network device
section.p: VRS‐G configuration includes setting up the port and VLAN ranges that are to be available to access the VSD. By default, the VRS‐G boots with all its ports configured as the network type, and therefore it has no VLANs available.
Use the following command to change eth0 from network to access and allow VLANs.

ol.li:
From the lifecycle manager, SSH to the VRS-G nodes using the default username and password.
User Name: cghelion Password: cghelion
Execute the following command to switch to the root user:sudo su -

Execute the following command, using your VLAN ID. nuage-vlan-config mod eth0 Access <vlad-id-range>
For example, if your VLAN ID is 1508:nuage-vlan-config mod eth0 Access 1500-2000

section.title: Configure the VRS-G
section.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade installation creates the required VRS-G gateway. You need to use the HPE DCN Virtualized Services Directory Architect (VSD) interface to add the gateway and configure the eth0 port.

p.i: For more information on performing this task, refer to the latest DCN documentation

ol.li: Log into the VSD dashboard.
Click Platform Configuration, then the Infrastructure tab, then click the Data Center Gateways icon. The new gateway appears in the Pending Gateways list on the left.
Click the blue arrow next to one of the new gateways to manage that gateway.
Add a port for the gateway by clicking Create a Port in the second panel from the left.
Enter the information as required, specifying eth0 in the Physical Name field and entering the VLAN ID for the external network. Also, change the Type field to Access.

Click Create.
The VLAN and other ports will appear similar to the following:

body.section:
Assign permissions to the VRS-G There are two types of permissions, Use Permissions and Extend Permissions. Use Permissions allow members in the assigned group to use an object. Extend Permissions allow the members of an assigned group to use an object and to allow other groups to use the object. For this installation, you can select Use Permission.
For more information on performing this task, refer to the latest DCN documentation
To assign permissions:
In the VSD dashboard.
Select the gateway you created and click Add a Permission.
The Select Groups dialog appears. The default permission, allowed to use the object is displayed at the bottom of the popup.
Select an organization and click Select. Members of this group will be able to use the gateway.

section.title: Create a subnet for the floating IP
section.p: Use the following steps to create a subnet for the floating IP.
Note: You will need the floating IP subnet name during the installation when you create and edit a cURL script.

p.i: For more information on performing these tasks, refer to the DCN documentation

ol.li: In the VSD dashboard, click Platform Configuration, then Shared Network tab.
Click the + icon to create a floating IP pool subnet.
Click Create and default route information generated.

For the floating IP subnet, right-click and select Edit to get the subnet name.
Make note of this name, as you will use it to tun the cURL script in the following step.

section.title: Run a cURL script to enable floating IPs on the VRS-G

section.p: This script creates the uplink on the VRS-G, which is a requirement for the EXT-NET to function with HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade.

ol.li: From the KVM Host, copy the following code to create a cURL script.

Modify the cURL script for your environment:
FIP_NAME is the one that is retrieved from previous step.
GW_NAME is the redundant gateway name.
All the UPLINK info are from the core switch on their specific testbed # IANA has reserved 192.0.0.0/29 for DS-lite transition # UPLINK_SUBNET="10.20.9.0" UPLINK_MASK="255.255.255.192" VRSG_IP="10.20.9.2" #DUncan Modified :P UPLINK_GW="10.20.9.1" # ROUTER IP ON SWITCH main switch 10.1.64.21 UPLINK_GW_MAC="bc:ea:fa:1d:b0:80" # VLAN 1209 MAC address not VRSG is from main switch 10.1.64.21 #UPLINK_GW_MAC="78:48:59:4f:fb:3c" # VLAN 1209 MAC address not VRSG is from main switch 10.1.64.21
if [ $# -eq 1 ]; then # remote install echo "Performing remote install to root@'$1' (requires PermitRootLogin=yes in sshd config)..." ssh root@$1 'bash -s ' < $0 exit 0 elif [ $# -ne 0 ]; then cat <<END Usage (as root) $0 [remote IP] END exit -1 fi
# Install required software packages, if not already if [ -e /usr/bin/yum ]; then [[ `which jq` != "" ]] || yum install -y jq \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources | jq -r '.[0].parentID'` if [ "$ZONE_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Error: Floating IP pool named '$FIP_NAME' not found" exit 1 fi
# Lookup VLAN to use GW_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: name=='$GW_NAME'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/gateways | jq -r '.[0].ID'` PORT_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: name=='$PORT_NAME'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/gateways/$GW_ID/ports | jq -r '.[0].ID'` VLAN_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: value==$VLAN" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/ports/$PORT_ID/vlans | jq -r '.[0].ID'` if [ "$VLAN_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Error: VLAN on gateway '$GW_NAME' with port '$PORT_NAME' and value '$VLAN' not found" exit 1 fi echo "VLAN $VLAN ID: $VLAN_ID"
# Get/Create uplink subnet SUBNET_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: type=='UPLINK_SUBNET'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ # Get/Create uplink subnet SUBNET_ID=`curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Filter: type=='UPLINK_SUBNET'" -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources | jq -r '.[0].ID'` #if [ "$SUBNET_ID" == "" ]; then echo "Creating new FIP uplink subnet in ZONE $ZONE_ID" curl -ks -H "X-Nuage-Organization: CSP" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: XREST $TOKEN" \ https://$VSD_IP:8443/nuage/api/v3_0/sharednetworkresources -d "{ \ \"name\": \"FIP uplink subnet\", \ \"description\": \"uplink subnet\", \ \"address\": \"$UPLINK_SUBNET\", \ \"netmask\": \"$UPLINK_MASK\", \ \"gateway\": \"$VRSG_IP\", \ \"type\": \"UPLINK_SUBNET\", \ \"uplinkInterfaceIP\" : \"$UPLINK_GW\", \ \"uplinkInterfaceMAC\" : \"$UPLINK_GW_MAC\", \ \"sharedResourceParentID\" : \"$ZONE_ID\", \ \"uplinkGWVlanAttachmentID\" : \"$VLAN_ID\", \ \"uplinkVPortName\" : \"uplink vport1\" \ }" #else #echo "FIP uplink subnet already exists: $SUBNET_ID" #fi ##########
Save and close the script.

Execute the cURL script bash +x <script_name>.sh
Where: <script_name> is the name of the cURL script you created.

Use the VSD dashboard to confirm that uplink port appears
Click Monitoring Console.
Click Nuage-VSP, then the VSC-1, then the VRS-G node under VRs. The IP address for the VRS-G VR is in the cURL script, if needed.

section.title: Create a Layer 3 Domain Template
section.p: A domain is a single Layer 3 space. A Domain Template contains components to define a domain, including domain zones, subnet pools, and security policies. A domain template can be used to create a domain instance. You can either use the default template or create a new L3 Domain Template.
section.i: For more information on performing these tasks, refer to the DCN documentation
section.p:
To create a Layer 3 Domain Template:
In the VSD dashboard, click Platform Configuration.
Click the organization you created previously.
Click the Networks tab.
A default L3 Template is created for the organization. You can edit this template or create a new template.
Select the template and click the Designer tab.
Double-click Zone Template and Public Zone Template in the Object Library to add the zones to the template.
Click the Policies tab.
Click the blue Ingress Security Policies icon.
Click the + icon to create a new policy
Enter a name and description for the policy.
Select Forward IP traffic by default.
Select Enable this policy.
Click Create.
Select the ingress policy you created.
Click the + icon to create a new ingress policy entry.
Click Apply Policy Changes. The policy is effective only when it is applied.
Click the blue Egress Security Policies icon.
Click the + icon to create a new policy
Enter a name and description for the policy.
Select Deploy Implicit Rules and Forward IP Traffic by Default.
Make sure Make This Policy Active is selected.
Select Enable this policy.
Click Create.
Select the egress policy you created.
Click the + icon to create a new ingress policy entry.
Click Apply Policy Changes. The policy is effective only when it is applied.
When the domain template is created, the domain template can be used to create a domain instance.

body.section:
Instantiate a Layer 3 Domain TemplateAfter defining a Domain Template, the domain template can be used to create a domain instance. A domain instance is created from a domain template and must be assigned a unique name as well as a unique Route Target and Route Distinguisher. A domain instance inherits all the properties from the domain template. Therefore after instantiation, the domain instance will have the Zones, Subnets and security policies defined in the Domain Template. All the naming for those elements are the same as the names defined on the Domain Template.
For more information on performing these tasks, refer to the DCN documentation
To instantiate a domain template:
In the VSD dashboard, click Platform Configuration.
Select the domain template you created.
Click the Instantiate icon.
Enter a name and description for the instance.
Click Instantiate.
Select the new instance under My L3 Domains and click the Designer tab.
Double-click Zone Template 0 in the Object Library to add the zone to the instance.
Double-click Subnet in the Object Library to add a subnet to the zone.
Launch a new browser session and enter VSD debug mode:
https://<vsd ip>:8443/?debug
Select the new subnet and pickup UUID from debug log:. HEAD https://10.20.5.21:8443/nuage/api/v3_2/subnets/239f0521-973c-44d9-98d8-4442185f5b45/vports (200):Debug log can be checked on web Console of Dev Tools on Browser:

section.title: Operations to be Performed on the non-KVM controller0
section.p: Perform the following steps on the on the non-KVM controller0.

ol.li:
Login to non-KVM controller0
sudo su -
Source the stackrc file: source stackrc

Map the organization created in VSD to HCG artifact:
Create a net partition with same organization name that you created in VSD.
neutron nuage-netpartition-create <org_name>
Where <org_name> is the name of the organization you created in VSD.
Create a local network
neutron net-create localnet1 neutron net-show localnet1
Create subnet for the network created above
neutron subnet-create --name localnet1subnet1 localnet1 <localnet-ip> --allocation-pool start=10.51.77.50,end=10.51.77.250 --nuagenet <UUID> --net-partition <partition-name> --enable-dhcp
Where:
<localnet-ip> is the network range that was provided for vsdsubnet during l3 domain creation. For example: 10.51.77.0/24.
<UUID> is the UUID of the subnet created in VSD. For example: 239f0521-973c-44d9-98d8-4442185f5b45.
<partition-name> is the name of the partition created in the previous steps.

Launch a VM.
nova boot --flavor m1.tiny --image cirrosvmdk --security-groups default --nic net-id=<Private NetworkID> cirvm1
Note: This VM will be detected and displayed in VSD

section.title: Operations to be performed on VSD

ol.li: In the VSD dashboard, click Platform Configuration.
Click the organization you created previously.
Click the Networks tab.
Double-click the L3 domain you instantiated. Click the domain icon in the design area, if needed.

Allocate floating IPs from the IP pool:
Click the floating IP icon in the top right corner.
Select the + icon to add a floating IP to allocation pool.
In the Claim Floating IP from Shared Network, select one of the network ranges.
Click Select.
The floating IP network range is displayed as a list item in the panel on the right.

Associate floating IP for the selected VM:
Select the Vport icon for the virtual machine you want to assign the floating IP.
Click the floating IP icon in the top right corner.
To select a floating IP address, click the link icon on the lower left. A list of ranges appears.
Select a range from which your floating IP address is to be assigned and click Select.
To assign the IP address to the VM, click the Update button at the bottom of the panel.
Verify that the IP address was associated to the VPort by referring to the VM details.
Verify FIP functionality by using tools such as Ping and SSH from outside the cloud server using the floating IP address.
